Sound 9/10Fitting music, with mystical/mysterious tones as well as the typical fast-paced stuff when things get heavy for Lara.Graphics 9/10For a game released in 2007 and a remake of an old game which had horrendous graphics (I lived through that age of heavy pixels) I was satisfied with what was presented in this game. The surrounding environment, in the temples and such were not unpleasant to look at.Gameplay 7.5/10As I mentioned that I never played any previous Tomb Raider games, I still knew what to expect since it was based on the older games. It’s 90% running around, pushing boxes, jumping, rolling, climbing, and/or solving puzzles. 10% using guns.Side note: I wonder why Lara has infinite ammo for her starting pistols? And this is eventually relevant to the story in the final boss fight which made me chuckle, you’ll find out if you get there.-Jumping and rolling is cool, as Lara is acrobatic so she can do flips or a handspring. Also, for jumping onto far ledges you might lose your grip and have to press E to fix it, so that’s a cool addition to the genre of platforming games. When the opportunity is present, you can use your grappling hook to run across walls or swing across a room, though the controls combined with the camera angle made it annoying sometimes to jump to where you wanted to go.-Additionally with camera angles, they were sometimes annoying during climbing. E.g. you’re on a ledge, and you may need to jump to behind you (180 degrees). But sometimes I didn’t know that beforehand, so while you’re hanging on a ledge, the camera can’t move to see behind you for some reason.-As for guns, you get a few additional weapons that you discover. What’s cool is the rare enemies you do actually face, is the dodging move, where time slows down a bit and if you time it right you can deliver a critical hit after rolling out of the way.-Targeting multiple enemies is a bit of a pain. The rare time there are multiple enemies that can give you trouble, perhaps I just missed what proper way to do so, but I was using my mouse to switch targets but it is not a smooth transition at all, almost unresponsive at times.-Some puzzles and proper routes felt challenging, at least for me. I ended up looking at video walkthroughs many, many times to avoid wasting time. I’m a crappy tomb raider.-Sometimes controls feel shtty, this is probably the top two gripes I have with the game (the first being a lack of action/gun play). Jumping and reaching where you want to go is not as easy and smooth as I would like (It doesn’t happen every time, but it’s something that definitely negatively affects the experience). I probably swore more times from missing jumps than any other game I’ve every played.There was even one point, climbing up the same ladder, I pressed the same controls to jump (as I did successfully did before) but it wouldn’t let me reach the ledge. I ended up jumping onto a wall and then falling, taking some damage. This is definitely more annoying than the Assassin’s Creed games.All in all, I have mixed emotions on finally completing this game. I’m happy to finally complete a tomb raider experience cuz it has spawned so many games. On the other hand, this game is not one I will probably ever play again. I have no desire to touch Croft Manor, whatever extra gameplay it offers aside from story mode.Overall score for me is 7.5/10If I was a gazillionaire, I'd offer a million dollars to anyone who hasn't played the game before to beat this game (with the assist of a video walkthrough) with only ten lives. That's how frustruated I was at times with the controls resulting in many, many falls to my death.

												I played this game first on PS2. PS2. My god. That is so weird.This is an excellent adaptation of both the games, and the character. I feel like this Lara is closer to the Lara I wanted to see when the first game came out. She's kind of cold and distant, maybe a little aristocratic, almost. I've heard a lot of people complain about how she seems too "angry" and that she's not "flirty" with Larsen anymore. Those people are dumb. Lara is much more appealing and much more interesting when she's not whatever the scene needs to her to be; Lara is consistent in Anniversary, as a character, and as a person. Her character builds and changes throughout the game, rather than being a static mouthpiece for the original writers to act out childish, sexist fantasies. This may not be a character we always like--she's like an antihero in that way--but we can always empathize with her, because she's more human when she has flaws.The gameplay is fantastic, the game is solidly built/programmed--I've never encountered a glitch in this game, and I must have played it on my PS2 through at least 3 or more times. The game is also beautiful, even if, much like in the first game, it suffers from inconsistent lighting and sometimes a wonky camera.
